discussion.content:
Port 80 is http
port 636 is LDAP
port 5800 is VNC
port 1433 is SQL

Out of all of there only LDAP is listed. answer is A. LDAP
lol the is answer A.

comments.content: Why wouldn't Secure-LDAP 636 with encryption be considered as an option of "securely provide access"??

discussion.content: Trick question. Real question : how to securely provide access to 3rd party for authentication. would be RADIUS in this case.
port 636 is LDAP
A radius port is 1812

choices.B: Install a firewall and IDS between systems and the LAN
choices.D: Upgrade the software on critical systems
choices.E: Configure the systems to use government-hosted NTP servers
choices.C: Employ own stratum-0 and stratum-1 NTP servers
choices.A: Isolate the systems on their own network

comments.content:
I've seen stratum 0 NTP Servers on more than 700 on-premise systems. It is costly but not impossible. 
Answer C is still a feasible approach

discussion.content:
You would hope the LAN would already have an edge firewall in place. . The firewall and IDS between the LAN and the Systems themselves would help protect from insider attacks I would think.

I don't think you can set up your own stratum 0. I think they have to be atomic clocks
Look at this reference wikipedia:
Stratum 0
 These are high-precision timekeeping devices such as atomic clocks, GPS or other radio clocks. They generate a very accurate pulse per second signal that triggers an interrupt and timestamp on a connected computer. Stratum 0 devices are also known as reference clocks. NTP servers cannot advertise themselves as stratum 0. A stratum field set to 0 in NTP packet indicates an unspecified stratum.[25] 

Here are some time servers from NIST:
https://tf.nist.gov/tf-cgi/servers.cgi
I believe NIST only runs stratum 1 time and not stratum 0. 

Maybe you can... I am not a system engineer so take it for what it's worth.

The answers I would choose are:
B. Install a firewall and IDS between systems and the LAN
E. Configure the systems to use government-hosted NTP servers

comments.content: the question calls for two answers
i agree that E has to be in the answer.

But one of those answers is: E. Configure the systems to use government-hosted NTP servers.
I don't see answers that protect the systems from the internet. Unless we are to understand that the systems get to the internet via the LAN.

discussion.content:
This may be a correct answer: B. Install a firewall and IDS between systems and the LAN
But would it not make more sense to Install a firewall and IDS between systems and the internet?
The answer given is correct.

comments.content: you are wrong and tek is right. https://timetoolsltd.com/ntp/what-is-a-stratum-1-time-server/
i stand corrected (so does tek). I missed the internet time source at first.
So now you think the correct answer is: E. Configure the systems to use government-hosted NTP servers ?
The systems have to pull from the Internet time sources. Having your own NTPs would make that internal time sources. Answer is correct.

discussion.content:
B. Install a firewall and IDS between systems and the LAN
C. Employ own stratum-0 and stratum-1 NTP servers

questions.question_text: An architect was recently hired by a power utility to increase the security posture of the company's power generation and distribution sites. Upon review, the architect identifies legacy hardware with highly vulnerable and unsupported software driving critical operations. These systems must exchange data with each other, be highly synchronized, and pull from the Internet time sources. Which of the following architectural decisions would BEST reduce the likelihood of a successful attack without harming operational capability? (Choose two.)

comments.content: Yes BEH is the correct answer.

discussion.content:
B. Data retention policy- Applies to taxation docs storage of 5 years & destroy customer info after 1 year. 
E. Data sovereignty policy- Applies to keeping data in customers home country. 
H. Encryption standard - Defines what "encrypted format" should be to store addresses.

Selected Answer: BEH
B. Data retention policy
E. Data sovereignty policy
H. Encryption standard

Given answers are correct. They address the SPECIFIC requirements listed. A legal compliance policy is too broad to be an answer here.

Maybe:
B. Data retention policy
D. Legal compliance policy
E. Data sovereignty policy 
Surprised that nobody thinks legal compliance is part of the answer.
From the question: "(CISO) and *legal team* agree . . ."
If the legal team is involved, then certainly legal compliance is at issue. 
Encryption standard should be part of retention policy, i.e. "customers addresses should be retained using AES-256 standard.."
Where am I wrong?
BEH is the correct Answer as stated above

Maybe: D. Legal compliance policy ?
Seems like it should be there.

questions.question_text:
A business is growing and starting to branch out into other locations. In anticipation of opening an office in a different country, the Chief Information Security
Officer (CISO) and legal team agree they need to meet the following criteria regarding data to open the new office:
✑ Store taxation-related documents for five years
✑ Store customer addresses in an encrypted format
✑ Destroy customer information after one year
✑ Keep data only in the customer's home country
Which of the following should the CISO implement to BEST meet these requirements? (Choose three.)
A company contracts a security engineer to perform a penetration test of its client-facing web portal. Which of the following activities would be MOST appropriate?

choices.B: Scan the website through an interception proxy and identify areas for the code injection
choices.D: Use network enumeration tools to identify if the server is running behind a load balancer
choices.A: Use a protocol analyzer against the site to see if data input can be replayed from the browser
choices.C: Scan the site with a port scanner to identify vulnerable services running on the web server

discussion.content:
I would choose:
 B. Scan the website through an interception proxy and identify areas for the code injection 

If you look at the OWASP top 10 vulnerabilities number 1 is injection:

A1:2017-Injection: Injection flaws, such as SQL, NoSQL, OS, and LDAP injection, occur when untrusted data is sent to an interpreter as part of a command or query. The attacker’s hostile data can trick the interpreter into executing unintended commands or accessing data without proper authorization.

A intercept proxy will allow you to easily tamper with the requests being sent back and forth including stuff like cookies, post and get parameters, and header data. 

Most of these flaws are somewhat independent of the underlying technology, minus if you do get code execution you will need to figure out syntax ie PHP or for sql injection what DBMS is running but you can fuzz to figure all of that out .

comments.content: Agree completely. CompTIA is more interested in trying to trip people up with unfair trick question, than in trying to test relevant knowledge.

i get that, it's just frustrating to study something extensively, just for it to relate more to instinct and get random stuff like this on the test, with answers talking about how a CEO is a social drinker and garbage like that. People pay good money for these tests, and its almost like they're jerking them around with some of the Q/A's, rather than trying to gauge aptitude. I'm definitely venting
If it were not for questions like this, everybody would pass. Then employers would think the exam is too easy.

discussion.content: why do they have questions like this? I guess C. i dont understand what comptia is trying to assess with questions like this

I would choose B. The question states pentest of client facing web 'portal' not server . This indicates some sort of username password fields or types of input to manipulate. Port scan would just give minimal or some known info like port 80 and 443 is open and web sever type.

C. Scan the site with a port scanner to identify vulnerable services running on the web server 
To see how else to attack the server.

comments.content: That’s a good point. Another badly worded question. However scanning ports can also help us determine version of the web app, which may help identify vulnerabilities. I do agree that scanning the web app with Burp Suite to identify areas for code injection would be feasible as well. Both would be things a pen tester would do... can only hope I don’t run across this one on the test... B&C seem correct. (If I had to choose, I would choose C. as it would be the first step when pentesting the web app”

discussion.content:
Well, technically to "perform a penetration test of client-facing
*web portal*", you should "Scan the website through an interception proxy and identify areas for the code injection".
Other answers are addressing pentesting other things. C would be to pwn the host itself, not assessing the web interface itself.
very vague lol, but c is the most appropriate
C. Scan the site with a port scanner to identify vulnerable services running on the web server

questions.question_text:
A large enterprise with thousands of users is experiencing a relatively high frequency of malicious activity from the insider threats. Much of the activity appears to involve internal reconnaissance that results in targeted attacks against privileged users and network file shares. Given this scenario, which of the following would
MOST likely prevent or deter these attacks? (Choose two.)

choices.F: Implement application blacklisting enforced by the operating systems of all machines in the enterprise
choices.E: For all workstations, implement full-disk encryption and configure UEFI instances to require complex passwords for authentication
choices.C: Enforce command shell restrictions via group policies for all workstations by default to limit which native operating system tools are available for use
choices.B: Increase the frequency at which host operating systems are scanned for vulnerabilities, and decrease the amount of time permitted between vulnerability identification and the application of corresponding patches
choices.D: Modify the existing rules of behavior to include an explicit statement prohibiting users from enumerating user and file directories using available tools and/or accessing visible resources that do not directly pertain to their job functions
choices.A: Conduct role-based training for privileged users that highlights common threats against them and covers best practices to thwart attacks

discussion.content:
I believe "C. Enforce command shell restrictions via group policies for all workstations by default to limit which native operating system tools are available for use " is referring to using group policy to limit access to the command prompt and powershell and even the "run" program too. 

Check out this article:
https://answers.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/forum/all/my-command-prompt-has-been-disabled-by/4585aff2-bdbb-4990-b976-5f272b58851c
https://www.howtogeek.com/249007/how-to-disable-the-command-prompt-and-run-program-in-windows/

As justaguy90 points out
Disabling these tools would help prevent the insider from "Living off the Land" for recon(very hard to detect) and force them to drop tools on disk that AV/EDRs could detect.

I would then adjust the rules of behavior so that I have legal standing to punish users that break the rules. Hard to hold users accountable if not written in policy.

Just my $.02

comments.content: Again, C is not how group policy even really works. Anyone who's ever written a group policy knows that it doesn't explicitly prohibit commands from going through the shell, and there's nothing in the question to suggest that insider threats are attacking privileged users from the command line at their workstation. That would be pretty easy to track and take care of. A is the only one that makes sense. Teach your users how to defend themselves--change passwords, lock systems, encrypt files, yadda yadda...

discussion.content:
A. wouldn't make sense. A user is not going to notice that there is ongoing enumeration of file and network shares. They won't be the one's who stop the attack. 

C&D are definitely correct. C would limit the tools available to the adversary, and D ensures that authorized users are aware that they should not be performing file/user enumeration.
C & D would be rigfht

comments.content:
I see no appreciable difference between C and F, and I do not believe these technical controls answer the question appropriately. Also "enforcing shell command restriction via group policy" is a sketchy definition at best of how Group Policy blocks access (are we disabling powershell????). A and D are the correct answer:
A: Conduct role based training to help individuals thwart social engineering attack (required by question)
D: This is the same as a Government Warning banner. Anyone who's worked on a government system (think checking the status of anything with your SSN like a stimulus check) gets these notices every time they log in "Your activity is being monitored and you have consented to monitoring and searching and blah blah blah do not violate our rules or we will arrest you and send you to FBI prison. This system for authorized use only." These notices are standard practice for all sensitive Information Systems, and act as a deterrent from doing things like stealing peoples SSNs to get their sensitive financial information, and alerts users who would misuse the system that they will be very easy to prosecute having been warned.

discussion.content: C and D seem right to me. C addresses prevention, by reducing the the availability of tools, and D specifically addresses deterrence, which is to discourage an attacker through fear of consequences, like a "NO TRESPASSING" sign or visible security cameras.

A. Conduct role-based training for privileged users that highlights common threats against them and covers best practices to thwart attacks
C. Enforce command shell restrictions via group policies for all workstations by default to limit which native operating system tools are available for use

(A) would train privileged users to thwart attacks as they are insider threats. 
(C) This would not allow regular users to use cmd prompts for internal recon. 

I do not think (D) b/c the attacks are from insiders and if you modify the rules of behavior (just a policy document, right?) then this is just more jargon for them to avoid. Locking their cmd shell (C) would definitely stop some internal recon.

A, D
Rules of behavior should explicitly state that any unauthorized system scanning, or unauthorized access, is a serious violation. That should be made clear to all users.
Since attacks are directed against privileged users, those uses need to be trained to know what to do to thwart such attacks.

A,D
A--user training should be best option?
